DD_Attribute_Full.name: sampling_parameter_scale
DD_Attribute_Full.definition: The sampling_parameter_scale element specifies whether the sampling interval is linear or something other such as logarithmic.

Terminological_Entry.name: sampling_parameter_scale
Terminological_Entry.definition: The sampling_parameter_scale element specifies whether the sampling interval is linear or something other such as logarithmic.

DD_Permissible_Value_Full.value_meaning: The values of the independent variable in Exponential Uniformly Sampled data are given at uniform spacing of the exponential of some base b, a positive real number. That is, for independent variable x in the range [x1, xn], the sampling points xj satisfy: b^xj = b^x1 + (j-1)(b^xn - b^x1)/(n-1) for j = 1 ... n where the caret symbol (^) denotes exponentiation. For example, if the independent variable has values 0., 0.30103, 0.47712, 0.60206, ... and the base is 10, then the Exponential Uniformly Spaced data are given at 10^0., 10^0.30103, 10^0.47712, 10^0.60206, ... or 1, 2, 3, 4, ...
Values of Uniformly_Sampled are given at uniform (linear) spacings of an independent variable - for example, 1, 2, 3, 4, ...

The values of the independent variable, x, in Logarithmic Uniformly Sampled data are given at uniform spacing of the logarithm of x in some base, b, a positive real number. That is, for independent variable x in the range [x1, xn], the sampling points xj satisfy: log_b(xj) = log_b(x1) + (j-1)(log_b(xn) - log_b(x1))/(n-1) for j = 1 ... n where log_b(x) is the log of x in base b. For example, if the independent variable has values 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... and the base is 10, then the Logarithmic Uniformly Spaced data are given at 0, 1, 2, 3 ...
